text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Wednesday.
- Labour Minister Joso Skara denies accusations that state pension fund (MIORH) financed his flat or those of other MIORH officials.
- Osijek Mayor Kramaric signs contract with Novalic d.d. construction firm to build 25,000 square metres of business facilities including concert hall, the biggest investment in town in 20 years.
- Joint venture shoe factory Nimel financed by Italian investor Elena Dariva and Zeljko Nims opens in Bjelovar.
- European Union has invested 100 million kuna in reconstruction of Eastern Slavonia, says EU special envoy in Croatia Per Vinther.

- Croatia needs time to fully adjust to rules of world trade organisations it wishes to join, deputy prime minister Borislav Skegro says. Agriculture, securities and telecommunications will have to open up to foreign competition.
- Independent alternative healers causing health deterioration or death of a patient may face up to 10 years of jail according to new draft law.
- Croatia's foreign debt is expected to reach 75 percent of its exports by 1999, ranking it among countries with low debt rate, says Velimir Sonje in a commentary.
- Retail prices gain one percent in January, but increase in food prices reached 3.2 percent.
- Fima brokerage distributes 1,000 offers of Rijecka Banka shares, representing one quarter of its capital, to potential buyers, but old share-holders lobby against the sales.
- Analysis: Foreign banks give impetus to structural changes in Croatian banking system. Smaller banks will be swallowed by the big ones and some will try themselves out in investment banking.
- Internet had a proper start up in Croatia in 1996 when state post (HPT) launched a commercial link. The number of users is estimated at up to 35,000 at the moment.

- Heavy debts of 1.1 billion kuna hit 86 hoteliers hard. Situation most difficult on central and southern coast. Bank for reconstruction and development (HBOR) offers loans only to private hotels, which are still in minority.
- Much sought state bonds represented almost one quarter of the trade on Zagreb bourse last week.
- European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) will acqiure some 25 percent of Hypno Bank Croatia after 18.5 million kuna investment.
